pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 215, 388, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 7 Probability & Statistics 2 (S2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 326, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 462, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 590, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The lengths of logs are normally distributed with mean \(3.5 \mathrm{~m}\) and standard deviation \(0.12 \mathrm{~m}\). Describe fully the distribution of the total length of 8 randomly chosen logs. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 136, 96, 155]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 136, 923, 170]]<|/det|>
(i) A random variable \(X\) has mean \(\mu\) and variance \(\sigma^2\). The mean of a random sample of \(n\) values of \(X\) is denoted by \(\overline{X}\). Give expressions for \(\mathrm{E}(\overline{X})\) and \(\mathrm{Var}(\overline{X})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 183, 151, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 183, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
The heights, in centimetres, of adult males in Brancot are normally distributed with mean 177.8 and standard deviation 6.1. Find the probability that the mean height of a random sample of 12 adult males from Brancot is less than \(176 \mathrm{~cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 214, 920, 233]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 245, 151, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 244, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, whether it was necessary to use the Central Limit Theorem in the calculation in part (ii).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 262, 920, 280]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 308, 94, 326]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 920, 356]]<|/det|>
Joshi suspects that a certain die is biased so that the probability of showing a six is less than \(\frac{1}{6}\). He plans to throw the die 25 times and if it shows a six on fewer than 2 throws, he will conclude that the die is biased in this way.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 369, 153, 387]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 369, 789, 387]]<|/det|>
Find the probability of a Type I error and state the significance level of the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 370, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 769, 418]]<|/det|>
Joshi now decides to throw the die 100 times. It shows a six on 9 of these throws.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 432, 148, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
Calculate an approximate \(95\%\) confidence interval for the probability of showing a six on one throw of this die.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 448, 920, 466]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 494, 94, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 494, 920, 542]]<|/det|>
The masses of a certain variety of potato are normally distributed with mean \(180 \mathrm{~g}\) and variance \(1550 \mathrm{~g}^2\). Two potatoes of this variety are chosen at random. Find the probability that the mass of one of these potatoes is at least twice the mass of the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 526, 920, 543]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 571, 92, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
It is claimed that, on average, people following the Losefast diet will lose more than \(2\mathrm{kg}\) per month. The weight losses, \(x\) kilograms per month, of a random sample of 200 people following the Losefast diet were recorded and summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 628, 655, 645]]<|/det|>
\[n = 200\qquad \Sigma x = 460\qquad \Sigma x^2 = 1636\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 666, 156, 683]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 666, 690, 683]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 666, 920, 683]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 696, 153, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 696, 500, 714]]<|/det|>
Test the claim at the \(1\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 695, 920, 714]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Darts are thrown at random at a circular board. The darts hit the board at distances \(X\) centimetres from the centre, where \(X\) is a random variable with probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[381, 112, 611, 170]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{2}{a^2} x & 0\leqslant x\leqslant a,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 172, 361, 191]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 203, 156, 222]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 203, 710, 222]]<|/det|>
Verify that f is a probability density function whatever the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 203, 920, 222]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 234, 356, 252]]<|/det|>
It is now given that \(\mathrm{E}(X) = 8\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 266, 153, 284]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 266, 316, 284]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 266, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 297, 151, 315]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 297, 811, 315]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that a dart lands more than \(6\mathrm{cm}\) from the centre of the board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 297, 920, 315]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 343, 96, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 343, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
The number of workers, \(X\), absent from a factory on a particular day has the distribution \(\mathsf{B}(80, 0.01)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 375, 153, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 375, 920, 393]]<|/det|>
Explain why it is appropriate to use a Poisson distribution as an approximating distribution for \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 392, 920, 410]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 421, 153, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 421, 920, 454]]<|/det|>
Use the Poisson distribution to find the probability that the number of workers absent during 12 randomly chosen days is more than 2 and less than 6.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 437, 920, 456]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 467, 920, 502]]<|/det|>
Following a change in working conditions, the management wishes to test whether the mean number of workers absent per day has decreased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 515, 151, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 515, 920, 548]]<|/det|>
During 10 randomly chosen days, there were a total of 2 workers absent. Use the Poisson distribution to carry out the test at the \(2\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 532, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
